title: By person present
context: §803-3 By person present. Anyone in the act of committing a crime, may be arrested by any person present, without a warrant. [PC 1869, c 49, §3; RL 1925, §3969; RL 1935, §5402; RL 1945, §10703; RL 1955, §255-3; HRS §708-3; ren L 1972, c 9, pt of §1] Attorney General Opinions A police officer may arrest without a warrant if the police officer has probable cause to believe an offense is being committed in the police officer&rsquo;s presence, even though it be a violation. Att. Gen. Op. 76-4. Case Notes Arrest without warrant, legal. 14 H. 586 (1903). Police officer may arrest for a misdemeanor without warrant if, based on personal knowledge, police officer has probable cause to believe offense is being committed in police officer&rsquo;s presence. 56 H. 383, 538 P.2d 320 (1975). This authority extends to misdemeanors. 56 H. 675, 548 P.2d 268 (1976).
